annotation.summary: This chunk is a partially corrupted or merged tabletop RPG character sheet template, resembling a Pathfinder 2E-style layout. It includes sections for hero points, attributes, proficiencies, defenses, skills, and action icons. The text appears to combine multiple formatting layers, but the core mechanics and structure remain recognizable.
key_rules: Gain 1 Hero Point at the start of each session or when granted by the GM.
Spend 1 Hero Point to reroll a check.
Spend all Hero Points to avoid death.
Proficiency levels modify rolls: Untrained (+0), Trained (+2 + level), Expert (+4 + level), Master (+6 + level).
Armor and weapon proficiencies determine bonuses and available equipment.
Attributes provide partial boosts to derived statistics such as AC, saves, and skills.

action_economy.single_action: ❖ Single Action — represents one basic action in a turn.
action_economy.two_action: ❖ Two-Action Activity — consumes two actions for more complex tasks.
action_economy.three_action: Three-Action Activity — uses all actions in a turn for major effects.
action_economy.free_action: Free Action — does not consume an action but may have trigger conditions.
action_economy.reaction: Reaction — occurs in response to a trigger outside the character’s turn.

prerequisites: Character creation requires selecting ancestry, background, class, and assigning ability boosts.
Proficiency ranks depend on class and level progression.
annotation.query: coalesced TTRPG character sheet structure and hero point/action economy rules

annotation.summary: This chunk appears to be a section of a tabletop role-playing game (TTRPG) character sheet, outlining key character statistics, hero point mechanics, and defensive attributes. It includes placeholders for ancestry, background, class, and ability scores, as well as tracking for hit points, armor, and conditions.
key_rules: Gain 1 Hero Point at the start of each session and when granted by the GM.
Spend 1 Hero Point to reroll a check.
Spend all Hero Points to avoid death.
annotation.action_economy: Hero Points function as a meta-resource that can be spent outside normal turn actions to influence outcomes or prevent character death.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation requires defining ancestry, background, class, and assigning ability boosts.
annotation.query: Summarize the hero point system and core character attributes from this TTRPG sheet.

annotation.summary: This chunk appears to be a fragmented reference sheet for a tabletop role-playing game (TTRPG), listing various skills, their associated ability scores, proficiency modifiers, and item bonuses. It also references weapon traits, damage types, and strike types (melee and ranged).
key_rules: Each skill is tied to a specific ability score (e.g., Acrobatics — Dexterity, Arcana — Intelligence).
Proficiency and item bonuses modify skill checks.
Weapons have traits, range, and damage types (magical, physical, etc.).
Strikes are divided into melee and ranged categories.
Armor and equipment may influence skill or strike performance.
annotation.action_economy: Not explicitly stated, but implied standard TTRPG structure: actions for strikes, skill checks, and movement.
annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly listed; assumes character proficiency and ability score modifiers are prerequisites for skill use.
annotation.query: coalesced TTRPG skill and strike reference data

annotation.summary: This fragment appears to be a partially corrupted or coalesced section of a tabletop RPG character sheet or rule reference, listing traits, proficiencies, and skill associations. It references weapon proficiencies, critical specializations, and skills such as Stealth, Arcana, and Survival, along with proficiency levels and item bonuses.
key_rules: Weapon proficiencies determine which weapons a character can use effectively.
Critical specializations grant additional effects on critical hits depending on weapon type.
Skill proficiencies (e.g., Stealth, Arcana, Survival) are tied to ability modifiers and proficiency ranks.
Class DC may be used for class-specific abilities or checks.
annotation.action_economy: Not explicitly defined in this fragment; likely follows standard TTRPG action structure (actions, reactions, free actions).
annotation.prerequisites: None clearly stated; likely depends on class or background context not included in this chunk.
annotation.query: What are the intended proficiency progressions and how do they interact with class DCs in this coalesced data?

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines proficiency progression, action types, and level-based advancement structure for a tabletop RPG. It also includes inventory and bulk management rules, as well as feat and ability progression by level.
annotation.prerequisites: Character level progression determines access to ancestry feats, skill feats, class feats, and general feats.
annotation.query: Summarize proficiency and action economy structure from the provided TTRPG chunk.

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines a level-by-level progression structure for a tabletop RPG character, detailing when different types of feats, class features, and abilities are gained. It also includes inventory and bulk management rules, covering how items, encumbrance, and investment limits function.
key_rules: Characters gain specific feats and features at each level, including ancestry, class, skill, and general feats.
Bulk system defines carrying capacity: 10 light items equal 1 Bulk.
Encumbered Bulk equals 5 + Strength modifier; Maximum Bulk equals 10 + Strength modifier.
Maximum number of invested items is 10.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified in this chunk; focuses on progression and inventory rather than turn-based actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Character level determines access to new feats and features; Strength score affects Bulk limits.
annotation.query: Summarize the level progression and inventory rules from the provided TTRPG chunk.

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines a character creation or advancement section for a tabletop role-playing game, listing class features, wealth, skill feats, ability boosts, and class feats. It also includes a detailed character sketch template for recording personal and narrative details such as origin, home world, appearance, and personality.
key_rules: Track character wealth in credits and UPBs (Universal Polymer Base).
Assign skill feats, ability boosts, and class feats as part of character progression.
Record narrative and descriptive details in the character sketch section.
action_economy: Free actions and reactions are referenced, implying standard TTRPG timing structures for character abilities.
prerequisites: Character must have a defined class to gain class features and feats.
Certain feats or actions may require specific triggers or traits.
annotation.query: Summarize and extract the mechanical and narrative components of the character feature and sketch section.

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines a template or framework for recording a TTRPG character, NPC, or faction’s behavioral and mechanical details. It includes sections for personality, affiliations, and a structured list of actions, reactions, and traits.
key_rules: Attitude, deity/philosophy, edicts, and anathema define moral and behavioral alignment.
Likes, dislikes, catchphrases, and campaign notes provide roleplaying flavor.
Actions, free actions, and reactions are organized with associated traits, triggers, and effects.
Each entry references a page number for source documentation.

action_economy.actions: Standard actions performed on a turn.
action_economy.free_actions: Instant or narrative actions requiring no cost.
action_economy.reactions: Triggered responses occurring outside the normal turn order.

annotation.prerequisites: None explicitly listed; assumes use within a TTRPG system supporting action, reaction, and trait structures.
annotation.query: Summarize and structure the TTRPG chunk describing character attitudes, affiliations, and action templates.

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines the spellcasting framework for a tabletop RPG, describing how magical traditions, spell slots, and casting methods (prepared vs. spontaneous) interact. It also references spell ranks, spell statistics, and focus mechanics.
key_rules: Four magical traditions: Arcane, Divine, Occult, and Primal.
Two casting methods: Prepared Caster (pre-selects spells) and Spontaneous Caster (casts known spells).
Spell Ranks range from 1 to 10, determining spell power.
Spell statistics include Spell Attack and Spell DC, based on key proficiency and ability modifiers.
Focus Spells use Focus Points, with a Focus Pool equal to the number of focus spells (maximum 3).
Refocus activity restores 1 Focus Point after 10 minutes of rest or meditation.
annotation.action_economy: Casts typically require actions as defined by the spell (e.g., verbal, somatic, material components). Refocus requires 10 minutes of downtime.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must belong to a class or archetype granting spellcasting ability within one of the four magical traditions.
annotation.query: Summarize and extract the core spellcasting structure and mechanics from the provided TTRPG rules chunk.

annotation.summary: This chunk outlines the spellcasting framework for a tabletop RPG character, detailing different categories of spells (cantrips, focus spells, innate spells, rituals) and how they are prepared, ranked, and used.
key_rules: Cantrip rank equals half your level, rounded up.
Focus pool equals the number of focus spells you have, with a maximum of 3.
Refocus allows you to spend 10 minutes to regain 1 Focus Point.
annotation.action_economy: Each spell or ability lists its required actions. Refocus takes 10 minutes of downtime.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a base key proficiency and access to spellcasting features such as cantrips, focus spells, or rituals.
annotation.query: coalesced TTRPG spellcasting structure and resource recovery
